bestBHT.bht: On this occasion, Matthew uniquely mentions the presence of women and children, while the other Gospel writers only mention men. However, this does not imply that the women and children were neglected, but rather that the eaters included five thousand men, in addition to the women and children. It is possible that the number of women and children present was not as large due to the crowded nature of the event. This extraordinary miracle of feeding such a multitude emphasizes Jesus' remarkable power and drew a significant gathering, including women and possibly an equal number of children.

Henry Alford: Beside women and children is peculiar to Matt.
This might have been inferred from men being mentioned in the other three Evangelists.
Philip Schaff: Five thousand men. All the Evangelists mention the number of men. Matthew alone adds: besides women and children.
The latter classes were probably not numerous, and would be fed apart from the men.
On the effect of the miracle, see John 6:14-15.
Archibald T. Robertson: Perhaps on this occasion there were not so many as usual because of the rush of the crowd around the head of the lake.
Matthew adds this item and does not mean that the women and children were not fed, but simply that 'the eaters' (ο εσθιοντες) included five thousand men (ανδρες) besides the women and children.
John Gill: A large number indeed, to be fed with five loaves and two fishes!
And who might be near as large a number as the men.
For generally there is a very great concourse of the female sex, and of children, where anything extraordinary, or out of the way, is to be seen or heard.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 14:21, the mention of women and children is unique to Matthew's account. However, it can be inferred from the other Gospel writers that men were present as well. It is possible that on this particular occasion, the number of women and children was not as large due to the crowded nature of the scene. Matthew's emphasis on the eaters including five thousand men indicates that the women and children were also provided for. This miracle of feeding such a large crowd with only five loaves and two fishes highlights the extraordinary nature of Jesus' power and drew a significant gathering, including women and possibly an equal number of children.

On this occasion, the account in Matthew uniquely mentions the presence of women and children, in addition to the men as mentioned by the other Gospel writers. It is possible that the number of women and children present was not as large due to the crowded nature of the scene. Matthew's emphasis on the eaters including five thousand men suggests that women and children were also provided for. This miraculous feeding with limited resources showcases Jesus' power and attracts a significant gathering, including women and possibly an equal number of children.

On this occasion, Matthew uniquely mentions the presence of women and children, while the other Gospel writers only mention men. However, this does not imply that the women and children were neglected, but rather that the eaters included five thousand men, in addition to the women and children. It is possible that the number of women and children present was not as large due to the crowded nature of the event. This extraordinary miracle of feeding such a multitude emphasizes Jesus' remarkable power and drew a significant gathering, including women and possibly an equal number of children.

On this occasion, Matthew specifically mentions the presence of women and children, in addition to the men noted by the other Gospel writers. However, this does not imply neglect towards the women and children, but rather that the eaters consisted of five thousand men, along with women and children. The smaller number of women and children present may have been due to the large crowd surrounding the lake. This miraculous feeding demonstrated Jesus' extraordinary power and attracted a considerable gathering, including women and possibly an equally significant number of children.

Matthew's account uniquely includes the mention of women and children among the crowd. While the other Gospel writers focus on the number of men, Matthew clarifies that the eaters consisted of five thousand men, as well as women and children who were not neglected. The presence of women and children may have been less numerous on this occasion due to the crowded atmosphere. This miracle of feeding such a vast multitude with only five loaves and two fishes highlights the extraordinary power of Jesus and drew a significant gathering, possibly including an equal number of women and children.
